title: How to Make a Simple Toga Out of a Bedsheet

steps.title: Grab the corner of the bed sheet in one hand.
steps.content: Grab the corner of the bed sheet in one hand. Leave about 6-8 inches (15 - 20 cm) of the sheet in one hand to tie the knot with. Hold the bed sheet above either shoulder with the corresponding hand (left hand to left shoulder, right hand to right shoulder, etc.). [1] X Research source

steps.title: Drape the sheet snug across your chest.
steps.content: Drape the sheet snug across your chest. Then, tuck it under the opposite arm. [2] X Research source Wrapping the toga around your chest offers more coverage. Ask a friend to help wrap the toga around you if you have difficulty keeping it up as you go. Alternately, wrap the toga snugly around your waist for a toga that exposes half of your chest. Ohayon-Crosby recommends this method for men wanting to wear a one-sided toga.

steps.title: Shorten the toga if necessary.
steps.content: Shorten the toga if necessary. If the toga is too long, fold one edge over by about 6 inches (15 cm), and try again. Keep adjusting until you get the right length, which is around the knee area.

steps.title: Wrap the sheet around your body twice.
steps.content: Wrap the sheet around your body twice. Tuck the sheet under the arm you're holding it with. Then, wrap it around the front of your chest over the first wrap. Pass it under the opposite arm and across your back, ending at the back of your shoulder on the same side where you’re holding the corner in the front. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tie the corners of the bedsheet in a knot over your shoulder.
steps.content: Tie the corners of the bedsheet in a knot over your shoulder. Ohayon-Crosby says to bring the second corner of the sheet up over your back to the corner in your hand. Secure the two ends by tying them in a knot . For a more secure toga, use a brooch or pin. For another neck option, wrap the toga at your chest level from the back. Hold each corner an equal distance from your body, then cross them over each other and tie the ends behind your neck. Ohayon-Crosby recommends securing your toga at the waist to make sure it doesn’t fall. Use a couple of safety pins inside the toga if necessary. [4] X Research source Whether you need a Halloween costume or you’re joining a fraternity in a college Greek system, you’re all set to head to the party!

steps.title: Wrap the sheet around your waist.
steps.content: Wrap the sheet around your waist. Hold the corner of the sheet hip level at your left side, so it covers the front of your body and not the back. Wrap the sheet around your body until it overlaps the first corner by a few inches. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Pin the sheet in place to form a snug waistband.
steps.content: Pin the sheet in place to form a snug waistband. If you’re wearing fitted pants with a firm waistband, tuck the edge of the sheet into it all the way around your waist for extra security. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Toss the rest of the sheet over your right shoulder.
steps.content: Toss the rest of the sheet over your right shoulder. Allow the sheet to drape in a diagonal arc across your chest. If the sheet trails on the ground behind you, wrap it around your waist one more time before throwing it over your shoulder.

steps.title: Decide the length of your toga.
steps.content: Decide the length of your toga. It is recommended to use a twin sheet, though a full sheet also works (especially if you are taller). Fold the sheet lengthwise until it is the desired length of the final dress. [7] X Research source For a short toga, fold the sheet in half. For a longer toga, fold down only the top 6” to 1’.

steps.title: Fold the sheet in half widthwise around your body.
steps.content: Fold the sheet in half widthwise around your body. One half of the sheet covers the back of your body, and the other half covers the front. Keep the folded-down section at the top near your shoulder on the outside of the chiton.

steps.title: Join the front and back of the chiton with a pin at each shoulder.
steps.content: Join the front and back of the chiton with a pin at each shoulder. [8] X Research source Place the pins about 2 feet (60 cm) apart. This gives you enough room for the chiton to drape across your clavicle without falling off your shoulders. Buy fancy pins for the occasion or use safety pins.

steps.title: Place your arm through the hole.
steps.content: Place your arm through the hole. Pinning the sides creates a large armhole where the front of the sheet meets the back. Slip your arm through this hole to put the chiton on.

steps.title: Secure the waist with a belt.
steps.content: Secure the waist with a belt. Use a cord, ribbon, or a tight-fitting belt to tie the waist. You will probably need to overlap the open sides a bit before you secure the waist to ensure you don’t expose more skin than you’d like. If you’re concerned about the chiton gaping, whipstitch the edges together before putting it on. [9] X Research source
